fields.description:
The targeted value (as may be determined by a parent resource type) is: 2 * ${EBS.VolumeAttachment}  volumes that are available

The task is to evaluate what obstacles exist to reaching the target value (today) of 2 volumes for every ${EC2.Instance} that could be running = 20k

The first step is to:
# Evaluate whether the target can be achieved today
# Identify (file JIRAs for) the issues (bugs) to address in order to reach that value

The purpose of the task is to establish a baseline for this capacity limit in the system and use it to evaluate work on the issues which are identified as obstacles.

Priority backend: Ceph RBD
Most of our SAN backends do not support 20K volumes anyway. Ceph, DAS, and Overlay are the only backends that are expected to reach this level and DAS/Overlay are not considered production ready for a system of 10K instances, so can be omitted.

Total objective: 20K volumes in one cloud. Attachment state is not important (e.g. they do not need to be attached, nor do VMs need to be running).
Max volumes per account in AWS is 5000, so if that limit is imposed in Euca, may need to use multiple account evaluate this limit.

Verification steps:
Create volumes (up to 20K)
Describe volumes (each account will likely return only up to 5000)
Delete volumes

"Failure" if:
Volume cannot be created (API call returns error or volume fails to enter 'available' state) when it should be able to be--there is capacity in the system and no policy forbids it
OR
API operation exceeds 20 sec timeout'
OR
DescribeVolumes at the end does not return the correct list for the given account
OR
Volumes reported as 'available' are not available on the backend (e.g not in the storage backend yet)--this can be evaluated at the end of the creation phase, to simplify it with regard to concurrency
fields.summary: ILL: Evaluate EC2/EBS limits on Volume

comments.body:
Test plan:
{code}
# set max total volume size to 50000Gb
euctl --region localhost one.storage.maxtotalvolumesizeingb=50000

# create 100 accounts
for i in {1..100}
do
  mkdir /tmp/account-$i
  euare-accountcreate acct-$i
  euca-get-credentials /tmp/account-$i/admin.zip -u admin -a acct-$i
  unzip /tmp/account-$i/admin.zip -d /tmp/account-$i/
done

#create 400 volumes in each account
for i in {1..100}
do
  for j in {1..400}
  do
    source /tmp/account-$i/eucarc && { time euca-create-volume -z one -s 1 ; } 2>> /tmp/time.txt
  done
done

#check
for i in {1..100}
do
  total=`source /tmp/account-$i/eucarc && euca-describe-volumes | grep available | wc -l`
  echo "Account $i has $total available volumes"
done

#output time
cat /tmp/time.txt | grep real | awk '{ print $2}' | sort
{code}


Parallel create test after 40K volumes were created
{code}
# create.sh
echo $1
for j in {1..10}; do source /tmp/account-$1/eucarc && { time euca-create-volume -z one -s 1 ; } 2>> /tmp/time.txt; done
{code}
Test
{code}
for j in {1..30}
do ./create.sh $j &
done
{code}

With 2 clients at 14K of available volumes create volumes request was taking 1-2 sec.

With 4 clients creating volumes at about 15K of available volumes mark create volume request takes 2-3 sec. Volumes are going into creating state. Current distribution:
  14992 available
    954 creating

With 4 clients creating volumes at about 20K of available volumes mark create volume request takes 3-4 sec. Volumes are going into creating state. Current distribution:
   20165 available
   1136 creating

With 4 clients creating volumes at about 22.6K of available volumes mark create volume request takes 4+ sec. Volumes are going into creating state stay at about constant level. Current distribution:
  22635 available
   1166 creating

[~zhill], I've created 40K+ volumes. System worked! I did used simplest topology with CLC and SC collocated. Is that a valid test? 
With 40K volumes singe requests is processed in about 2.5c
I think response time depends on number of requests that are processed at the same time. I am adding a small test for that.
With 40K+ volumes and 6 parallel requests to create volume request takes up to 7.7 sec.

With 40K volumes and 30 parallel requests there timeouts and the one that succeed takes a while. The time is distributed from 7.714s to 1m57.682s
I guess this is end of my test. Passing this to [~zhill] for further investigation.
[~zhill], there is a chance that I've reached some sort of tipping point. Now describe-volumes does not work and times out :( I should have about 42-43K volumes created distributed over 100 accounts.
[~zhill], I've hit Java OutOfMemory trying to describe all volume as admin with verbose flag.
[~vasya], it is definitely ok to increase the heap size (-Xmx in CLOUD_OPTS) to be 4GB or more depending on hardware, we don't assume these scales of things are achievable on default settings.
[~zhill], I've created 20K volumes on a new set-up. The longest create volume response time was 4.0s.
[~vasya], for the next phase, please also test the single-account limit: 5000 volumes in a single account. For that test, 4 accounts with 5000 volumes each.
[~zhill], with 5000 volumes in an account describe-volumes take less than 1.5 sec.

Topologies used for tests:
- single clc/sc
- separate clc and sc
[~zhill], Do you have any additional test ideas?

[~vasya], no, this looks good. Please create a simple outcome table (here or in Confluence) with a full summary of the results including the configs used for each evaluation so we have it in a single page. Should just require copying the individual results from the comments on this page.
Basic testing complete. See comments in ticket for details. Testing was done against a Ceph cluster for EBS, and involved just creating and describing volumes in the 'available' state.
